Award.AwardTitle: 5th Lake Michigan Workshop on Combinatorics and Graph Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
The 5th Lake Michigan Workshop on Combinatorics and Graph Theory will
be held at the University of Notre Dame on April 21--22 2018.
The workshop will benefit graduate students and junior researchers in
the field of discrete mathematics, working at institutions in the Great Lakes area.
It is built around two sets of three tutorial lectures, focusing on state-of-the-art techniques and results that the speakers feel are underrepresented in typical graduate sequences, and
on emerging techniques on which the speakers are particularly
qualified to expound. There will also be short talks by students
and younger faculty members. There will be ample unscheduled time
during the weekend, allowing new research collaborations to
commence and active collaborations to be continued. Junior
participants will establish valuable connections with more senior
colleagues, and receive guidance from them in a relaxed and informal
environment.

The tutorial speakers for the 2018 workshop will talk about "Connections
between Coxeter systems, permutation patterns and reduced words", and "Edit distance in graphs". The website for the conference is https://www3.nd.edu/~conf/lmwcgt18/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 5th Lake Michigan Workshop on Combinatorics and Graph Theory was held at the University of Notre Dame on the weekend of April 21-22 2018. The workshop was primarily for the benefit of graduate students and junior researchers in the field of discrete mathematics, working at institutions in the greater Lake Michiga area. 

The workshop was built around two sets of three tutorial lectures. Bridget Tenner (DePaul University) gave three lectures on the connections between Coxeter systems (from represenation theory) and permutation patterns (from enumerative combinatorics), and Ryan Martin (Iowa State University) gave three lectures on his recent work on the concept of edit distance in graphs. There were also short talks on related topics given by graduate students and postdoctoral researchers.

There were 69 registered participants, including 4 undergraduates, 35 graduate students, among whom 16 were women. A specific objective of the workshop was to foster interaction between younger and more senior researchers. This was achieved by having blocks of time set aside on both days for discussion. This time was particularly fruitful on Saturday, when most of the student participants gathered together with some of the senior participants, and spend an hour discussing open problems in the field.  

Another specific objective was to focus the workshop on a combination of classical techniques and results that the speakers felt were under-represented in typical graduate sequences, and on emerging techniques on which the speakers were particularly qualified to expound. This objective was achieved by having Tenner given three hour-long talks on her interdisciplinary topic of coxter systems and permutation patterns, and having Martin give a series of talks on edit distance in graphs, an area in which he is an acknowledged expert.
